newsitem.title: USA: U.S. assessing Turkish plan for buffer zone in Iraq.
newsitem.headline: U.S. assessing Turkish plan for buffer zone in Iraq.

text.p: The United States said on Wednesday it was assessing a Turkish plan to create a security cordon inside northern Iraq to curtail Kurdish separatist activity along the border between the two countries.
State Department spokesman Glyn Davies said Turkey had informed the United States of its decision, but Washington had not yet responded.
"We will want to assess that in the broader framework of regional stability," he said.

A foreign ministry spokesman in Ankara said the zone would be five or 10 km (three to six miles) deep. Foreign Minister Tansu Ciller said earlier that Kurdistan Workers Party (PKK) guerrillas in northern Iraq had massed on the border, prompting Turkey to take the "necessary measures."

Davies noted that the United States had long supported Turkey's right to defend itself against attacks by PKK guerrillas, who have based themselves in the Western-protected Kurdish region in northern Iraq.

The Turkish plan follows last week's move by Iraqi forces into the Kurdish region, which prompted the United States to launch two cruise missile strikes this week on military installations in southern Iraq.
